title: Can you solve the death race riddle? - Alex Gendler

options.label: B

title: How you can use impostor syndrome to your benefit - Mike Cannon-Brookes

multiple-choice.question: What is "impostor syndrome"?

options.label: A
options.text: A feeling of being overwhelmed by too many tasks

options.label: B
options.text: A feeling of being well out of your depth, yet already entrenched in a situation

options.label: C
options.text: A fear of failure in a new situation

options.label: D
options.text: A feeling of being too confident in your abilities

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is one way to deal with impostor syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: To try to ignore the feeling and hope it goes away

options.label: B
options.text: To freeze and avoid taking any action

options.label: C
options.text: To try to learn as much as you can and turn the situation into a force for good

options.label: D
options.text: To pretend that you are not feeling like an impostor

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker's conversation with Belmiro de Azevedo reveal to him?

options.label: A
options.text: That he was not cut out for business

options.label: B
options.text: That he needed to work harder to be successful

options.label: C
options.text: That other people, even successful ones, can feel like impostors too

options.label: D
options.text: That he should just give up and go home

multiple-choice.question: What is one attribute of successful relationships, according to the speaker's research?

options.label: A
options.text: When one partner feels superior to the other

options.label: B
options.text: When both partners feel out of their league

options.label: C
options.text: When one partner is always in control

options.label: D
options.text: When both partners are always in agreement

multiple-choice.question: How did the speaker handle the situation when Elon Musk tweeted back at him about the battery proposal?

options.label: A
options.text: He froze and avoided responding

options.label: B
options.text: He tried to learn as much as he could about the topic and responded thoughtfully

options.label: C
options.text: He pretended to be an expert on the topic

options.label: D
options.text: He gave up and admitted defeat

title: How rap saves lives - Raegan Sealy

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is one of the benefits of rap music for young people?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps them to avoid their problems.

options.label: B
options.text: It provides a healthy outlet for emotions and experiences.

options.label: C
options.text: It encourages them to join gangs.

options.label: D
options.text: It promotes violence and aggression.

multiple-choice.question: The speaker mentions that rap music is often criticized for its explicit content, but what is their response to this criticism?

options.label: A
options.text: They agree that rap music is too explicit and should be censored.

options.label: B
options.text: They argue that the explicit content is a realistic reflection of the world we live in.

options.label: C
options.text: They suggest that rap music should only be listened to by adults.

options.label: D
options.text: They believe that rap music is only about violence and hate.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's experience with rap music, and how has it impacted their life?

options.label: A
options.text: They have never listened to rap music and don't understand its appeal.

options.label: B
options.text: They used to listen to rap music, but it had a negative impact on their life.

options.label: C
options.text: They discovered rap music as a teenager, and it helped them to express themselves and find their voice.

options.label: D
options.text: They have always hated rap music and think it's a waste of time.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is one of the unique aspects of rap music that sets it apart from other art forms?

options.label: A
options.text: It requires a lot of money and resources to produce.

options.label: B
options.text: It can only be performed by professionals.

options.label: C
options.text: It provides a platform for marginalized voices and communities to express themselves.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only about entertainment and not about social commentary.

multiple-choice.question: The speaker argues that rap music should be taken more seriously as an art form and suggests that it could be taught in schools. What is their reasoning for this?

options.label: A
options.text: They believe that rap music is more important than other subjects like math and science.

options.label: B
options.text: They think that rap music is a way to connect with young people and help them to express themselves in a healthy way.

options.label: C
options.text: They argue that rap music is only about entertainment and not about education.

options.label: D
options.text: They suggest that rap music should only be taught in music schools.

title: The Tower of Epiphany | Think Like A Coder, Ep 7

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of Ethic and Hedge in the tower?

options.label: A
options.text: To reach the top of the tower

options.label: B
options.text: To find the Node of Creation

options.label: C
options.text: To collect as much energy as possible

options.label: D
options.text: To solve a puzzle and progress upwards

multiple-choice.question: How does the energy behave when it pours down from above?

options.label: A
options.text: It spills out the front and back of the basin

options.label: B
options.text: It fills one unit at a time, with a force field preventing it from spilling out the front or back

options.label: C
options.text: It only fills the leftmost column of blocks

options.label: D
options.text: It only fills the rightmost column of blocks

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition for an unoccupied cell to hold energy?

options.label: A
options.text: There must be a wall eventually to its left

options.label: B
options.text: There must be a wall eventually to its right

options.label: C
options.text: There must be a wall eventually to its left and right

options.label: D
options.text: There must be no walls eventually to its left or right

multiple-choice.question: How does Hedge's algorithm work to determine the number of units of energy each column can hold?

options.label: A
options.text: He looks at each individual cell to determine if it can hold energy

options.label: B
options.text: He considers a whole column of blocks at a time and calculates the height of the energy that can fill up to

options.label: C
options.text: He looks only at the leftmost and rightmost columns of blocks

options.label: D
options.text: He looks only at the middle column of blocks

multiple-choice.question: What is the optimization that Hedge uses to reduce the time complexity of his algorithm?

options.label: A
options.text: He uses a loop that starts on the left-most column and moves right, one column at a time

options.label: B
options.text: He keeps a running tally of the highest stack to the left and right of each column

options.label: C
options.text: He looks at each column individually to determine the number of units of energy it can hold

options.label: D
options.text: He uses a recursive function to calculate the number of units of energy each column can hold

title: Why do people fear the wrong things? - Gerd Gigerenzer

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between absolute risk and relative risk?

options.label: A
options.text: Absolute risk is expressed as a percentage, while relative risk is expressed as a rate.

options.label: B
options.text: Absolute risk is the likelihood of an event occurring, while relative risk is the change in that likelihood.

options.label: C
options.text: Absolute risk is the change in the likelihood of an event occurring, while relative risk is the likelihood of that event.

options.label: D
options.text: Absolute risk is expressed as a rate, while relative risk is expressed as a percentage.

multiple-choice.question: A new drug reduces the risk of heart attacks by 40%. If 10 out of 1,000 people who didn't take the drug would have heart attacks, how many heart attacks would be prevented by taking the drug?
What is the problem with choices that reduce some risks?

options.label: A
options.text: They can put you in the path of other risks.

options.label: B
options.text: They can only reduce risks, not eliminate them.

options.label: C
options.text: They can only eliminate risks, not reduce them.

options.label: D
options.text: They have no impact on other risks.

multiple-choice.question: Why might someone be more strongly motivated to take a medication that lowers their heart-attack risk, even if it only provides a small reduction in absolute risk?

options.label: A
options.text: If they know they have a family history of heart disease.

options.label: B
options.text: If they know they have a family history of cancer.

options.label: C
options.text: If they are over 60 years old.

options.label: D
options.text: If they are under 40 years old.

multiple-choice.question: Why is risk evaluation tricky?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it involves statistical thinking and personal preference.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it only involves statistical thinking.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it only involves personal preference.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it involves neither statistical thinking nor personal preference.

title: How do blood transfusions work? - Bill Schutt

multiple-choice.question: In 1881, doctor William Halsted performed a blood transfusion on his sister Minnie. Why was the transfusion successful?

options.label: A
options.text: Because he used a new anticoagulant to prevent blood clotting.

options.label: B
options.text: Because he and his sister happened to have the same blood type.

options.label: C
options.text: Because he used a specialized machine to transfer the blood.

options.label: D
options.text: Because he had previously tested the blood for compatibility.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Jean-Baptiste Denis's experiment with blood transfusion in 1667?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient, Antoine Mauroy, was completely cured of his symptoms.

options.label: B
options.text: The patient developed a fever, severe pain, and intense burning in his arm.

options.label: C
options.text: The patient showed no significant improvement or deterioration.

options.label: D
options.text: The patient died immediately after the transfusion.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of antibodies in the immune response to a blood transfusion?

options.label: A
options.text: To recognize and destroy the body's own cells.

options.label: B
options.text: To recognize and latch onto foreign proteins (antigens) on the surface of transfused cells.

options.label: C
options.text: To prevent blood clotting and ensure smooth transfusion.

options.label: D
options.text: To stimulate the production of new red blood cells.

multiple-choice.question: What was Karl Landsteiner's discovery in 1901 that revolutionized blood transfusions?

options.label: A
options.text: The development of a new anticoagulant to prevent blood clotting.

options.label: B
options.text: The invention of a machine to transport and store blood.

options.label: C
options.text: The discovery of blood types and their importance in transfusion compatibility.

options.label: D
options.text: The creation of a blood bank system for hospitals.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the discovery of sodium citrate and heparin in the context of blood transfusions?

options.label: A
options.text: They were used to treat patients with blood-borne diseases.

options.label: B
options.text: They were used to stimulate the production of new red blood cells.

options.label: C
options.text: They were used as anticoagulants to prevent blood clotting and enable blood storage.

options.label: D
options.text: They were used to develop a new type of blood transfusion machine.

options.label: C

title: Epic Engineering: Building the Brooklyn Bridge - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What was the main problem with suspension bridges in Europe during the mid-19th century?

options.label: A
options.text: Their industrial cables were too expensive to maintain.

options.label: B
options.text: Their industrial cables frayed during turbulent weather and snapped under the weight of their decks.

options.label: C
options.text: They were not aesthetically pleasing.

options.label: D
options.text: They were not suitable for long distances.

multiple-choice.question: What type of bridge design did John Roebling propose for the Brooklyn Bridge?

options.label: A
options.text: A traditional suspension bridge design.

options.label: B
options.text: A cable-stayed bridge design.

options.label: C
options.text: A hybrid bridge model that combined elements of suspension and cable-stayed bridges.

options.label: D
options.text: An arch bridge design.

options.label: A
options.text: To excavate the river bottom and create the tower foundations.

options.label: B
options.text: To suspend the deck of the bridge.

options.label: C
options.text: To anchor the cables of the bridge.

options.label: D
options.text: To support the weight of the bridge's towers.

multiple-choice.question: What was the mysterious ailment that affected several workmen during the construction of the Brooklyn Bridge?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Tetanus.

options.label: C
options.text: Pneumonia.

options.label: D
options.text: Tuberculosis.

options.label: B
options.text: Washington Roebling's wife, Emily.

options.label: C
options.text: The chief engineer.

options.label: D
options.text: The city officials.

title: The accident that changed the world - Allison Ramsey and Mary Staicu

multiple-choice.question: What was the unexpected discovery made by Alexander Fleming in his lab in 1928?

options.label: A
options.text: A new species of bacteria

options.label: B
options.text: A colony of mold growing on a petri dish that had killed surrounding bacteria

options.label: C
options.text: A new type of virus

options.label: D
options.text: A new method for culturing bacteria

multiple-choice.question: How does penicillin destroy bacteria?

options.label: A
options.text: By disrupting the synthesis of their cell walls

options.label: B
options.text: By stimulating the release of highly reactive molecules that cause damage

options.label: C
options.text: By binding to one of the compounds that weaves the mesh of sugars and amino acids together

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: Why is penicillin not harmful to human cells?

options.label: B
options.text: Because human cells have a different type of cell wall

options.label: C
options.text: Because human cells don't have cell walls

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Underuse of the antibiotic

options.label: C
options.text: The antibiotic is not effective against certain types of bacteria

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of people who think they are allergic to penicillin actually are not?

options.label: D
options.text: Over 90%

options.label: D

title: The paradox of efficiency - Edward Tenner

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main problem with the concept of efficiency?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not achievable in most cases.

options.label: B
options.text: It can actually make us less efficient in the long run.

options.label: C
options.text: It is only applicable in certain industries.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not a desirable trait in today's society.

multiple-choice.question: What is the example given by the speaker of a situation where efficiency led to a negative outcome?

options.label: A
options.text: The use of electronic medical records.

options.label: B
options.text: The development of the potato as a food source in Europe.

options.label: C
options.text: The creation of the French 75-millimeter artillery piece.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the problem with relying solely on data and measurement to achieve efficiency?

options.label: A
options.text: It can lead to false positives and false negatives.

options.label: B
options.text: It can result in a lack of human intuition and skills.

options.label: C
options.text: It can cause a decrease in productivity.

options.label: D
options.text: It can lead to an increase in waste.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of "inspired inefficiency" proposed by the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea of intentionally introducing inefficiencies into a system to make it more efficient.

options.label: B
options.text: The concept of finding a balance between efficiency and inefficiency to achieve optimal results.

options.label: C
options.text: The practice of ignoring data and measurement to rely solely on human intuition.

options.label: D
options.text: The idea of eliminating all inefficiencies in a system to achieve maximum efficiency.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is one way to achieve "inspired inefficiency"?

options.label: A
options.text: By taking the scenic route and saying yes to serendipity.

options.label: B
options.text: By relying solely on data and measurement.

options.label: C
options.text: By eliminating all inefficiencies in a system.

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring human intuition and skills.

title: The Chasm | Think Like A Coder, Ep 6

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition for the hover-blocks to be stable and form a bridge across the ravine?

options.label: A
options.text: They must be arranged in a random sequence.

options.label: B
options.text: They must be arranged in a sequence that is the same when viewed forwards and backwards (palindromic).

options.label: C
options.text: They must be arranged in an alphabetical sequence.

options.label: D
options.text: They must be arranged in a sequence with no repeating blocks.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with the naïve solution of trying all possible arrangements of blocks to find a palindrome?

options.label: A
options.text: It would take too much energy.

options.label: B
options.text: It would take too much time.

options.label: C
options.text: It would require too many blocks.

options.label: D
options.text: It would not work at all.

multiple-choice.question: What is the pattern observed in the number of occurrences of each letter in a palindrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Most letters occur an odd number of times.

options.label: B
options.text: Most letters occur an even number of times, with at most one letter occurring an odd number of times.

options.label: C
options.text: All letters occur an even number of times.

options.label: D
options.text: All letters occur an odd number of times.

multiple-choice.question: How does Hedge's approach to finding a palindromic stack improve upon the naïve solution?

options.label: A
options.text: It takes less energy.

options.label: B
options.text: It takes less time (linear time instead of factorial time).

options.label: C
options.text: It requires fewer blocks.

options.label: D
options.text: It is more complicated.

options.text: She is safe with Ethic and Hedge.

options.label: B
options.text: She is not so lucky (implying that she falls into the ravine).

options.label: C
options.text: She finds a different way across the ravine.

options.label: D
options.text: She is not mentioned.

title: Licking bees and pulping trees: The reign of a wasp queen - Kenny Coogan

multiple-choice.question: What is the first task of a wasp queen after emerging from hibernation in the spring?

options.label: A
options.text: Building a new nest

options.label: B
options.text: Finding a mate

options.label: C
options.text: Searching for food

options.label: D
options.text: Defending against predators

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about a wasp's ability to sting compared to a bee's?

options.label: A
options.text: Wasps can only sting once

options.label: B
options.text: Wasps can sting as many times as they need to

options.label: C
options.text: Wasps can only sting in defense of their nest

options.label: D
options.text: Wasps cannot sting at all

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the first larva that hatch from the queen's eggs?

options.label: A
options.text: They become the new queens of the hive

options.label: B
options.text: They become the workers that forage for food and defend the hive

options.label: C
options.text: They become the drones that mate with the queen

options.label: D
options.text: They become the predators that feed on the hive

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of wasps to the ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: They pollinate flowers and fruits

options.label: B
options.text: They consume crop-eating insects and keep spiders and mites in check

options.label: C
options.text: They help winemakers by biting into grapes and jump-starting fermentation

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the workers in the hive as the days grow colder in autumn?

options.label: A
options.text: They prepare for hibernation

options.label: B
options.text: They migrate to a warmer location

options.label: C
options.text: They starve and die off

options.label: D
options.text: They become the new queens of the hive

title: How bones make blood - Melody Smith

multiple-choice.question: Where do the trillions of cells traveling through your blood vessels originate from?

options.label: A
options.text: Your heart

options.label: B
options.text: Your liver

options.label: C
options.text: Deep in your bones

options.label: D
options.text: Your brain

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of bone marrow in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce hormones

options.label: B
options.text: To filter waste

options.label: C
options.text: To produce blood cells

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate body temperature

multiple-choice.question: What is an allogeneic bone marrow transplant?

options.label: A
options.text: A transplant that replaces the patient's bone marrow with their own stem cells

options.label: B
options.text: A transplant that replaces the patient's bone marrow with a donor's stem cells

options.label: C
options.text: A transplant that replaces the patient's bone marrow with artificial stem cells

options.label: D
options.text: A transplant that replaces the patient's bone marrow with animal stem cells

multiple-choice.question: What is graft-versus-host disease?

options.label: A
options.text: A condition where the patient's immune system attacks the donor cells

options.label: B
options.text: A condition where the donor cells attack the patient's organs

options.label: C
options.text: A condition where the patient's immune system is weakened

options.label: D
options.text: A condition where the donor cells are rejected by the patient's immune system

multiple-choice.question: Why is it crucial to find a good match between the donor and the recipient in a bone marrow transplant?

options.label: A
options.text: To reduce the risk of infection

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce the risk of graft-versus-host disease

options.label: C
options.text: To increase the chances of successful transplant

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

title: The profound power of an authentic apology - Eve Ensler

multiple-choice.question: What is the main theme of the speaker's talk?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of punishing men who commit violence

options.label: B
options.text: The need for men to take responsibility and apologize for their actions

options.label: C
options.text: The impact of trauma on victims of abuse

options.label: D
options.text: The role of women in preventing men's violence

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the first step in making an authentic apology?

options.label: A
options.text: Asking for forgiveness

options.label: B
options.text: Making amends

options.label: C
options.text: Saying what you did in detail

options.label: D
options.text: Explaining why you did it

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker's father's experience as a child have to do with his later behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: He was abused as a child and repeated the pattern

options.label: B
options.text: He was adored and treated as the golden boy, but not allowed to express vulnerability

options.label: C
options.text: He was neglected and unloved

options.label: D
options.text: He was exposed to violence and aggression

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's goal in calling men "in" rather than "out"?

options.label: A
options.text: To shame and punish them for their actions

options.label: B
options.text: To encourage them to take responsibility and change their behavior

options.label: C
options.text: To ignore their wrongdoing and move on

options.label: D
options.text: To blame them for all societal problems

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the result of punishment alone in addressing men's violence?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an effective solution to the problem

options.label: B
options.text: It hardens the perpetrator but doesn't teach them

options.label: C
options.text: It has no impact on the perpetrator

options.label: D
options.text: It is a necessary step towards healing

title: What was so special about Viking ships? - Jan Bill

multiple-choice.question: Where did the Vikings originate from?

options.label: A
options.text: The Roman Empire

options.label: B
options.text: Scandinavia

options.label: C
options.text: Africa

options.label: D
options.text: North America

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary factor behind the Vikings' success in spreading throughout Europe and beyond?

options.label: A
options.text: Their central government

options.label: B
options.text: Their coinage system

options.label: C
options.text: Their ships

options.label: D
options.text: Their trade routes

multiple-choice.question: How did the Scandinavians initially build their canoes?

options.label: A
options.text: By hollowing out logs and adding planks using the clinker technique

options.label: B
options.text: By using iron nails and internal timbers

options.label: C
options.text: By sewing the planks together

options.label: D
options.text: By using copper, iron, and wood nails

multiple-choice.question: What was the significant change that the Scandinavians made to their ships after incorporating Roman maritime technology?

options.label: A
options.text: They replaced their loose paddles with anchored oars

options.label: B
options.text: They abandoned the log boat base for a keel plank

options.label: C
options.text: They added sails to their ships

options.label: D
options.text: They used internal frames and beams for added strength

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of adding sails to the Viking ships?

options.label: A
options.text: They became slower and less versatile

options.label: B
options.text: They became more costly to build and maintain

options.label: C
options.text: They became nearly unbeatable in terms of speed and distance

options.label: D
options.text: They became less seaworthy

title: Mating frenzies, sperm hoards, and brood raids: The life of a fire ant queen - Walter R. Tschinkel

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of a fire ant colony?

options.label: A
options.text: To build a large nest

options.label: B
options.text: To produce sterile workers

options.label: C
options.text: To aid the queen in reproduction

options.label: D
options.text: To spread the queen's genes

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the male fire ants after they mate during the nuptial flight?

options.label: A
options.text: They become the dominant ants in the colony

options.label: B
options.text: They start their own colonies

options.label: C
options.text: They die

options.label: D
options.text: They become workers

multiple-choice.question: How do fire ant queens establish their royal status?

options.label: A
options.text: By laying eggs

options.label: B
options.text: By breaking off their wings

options.label: C
options.text: By fighting off other queens

options.label: D
options.text: By producing venom

multiple-choice.question: What is brood-raiding in fire ant colonies?

options.label: A
options.text: When workers from one nest steal food from another nest

options.label: B
options.text: When queens from different nests mate

options.label: C
options.text: When workers from one nest steal offspring from another nest

options.label: D
options.text: When colonies merge to form a larger colony

multiple-choice.question: How do fire ant colonies typically come to an end?

options.label: A
options.text: When the queen dies of old age

options.label: B
options.text: When the colony is taken over by a neighboring colony

options.label: C
options.text: When the colony runs out of food

options.label: D
options.text: When the queen runs out of sperm and can no longer replace dying workers

title: The ballet that incited a riot - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: What was the audience's reaction to the first performance of Igor Stravinsky's "The Rite of Spring"?

options.label: A
options.text: They gave a standing ovation.

options.label: B
options.text: They were indifferent.

options.label: C
options.text: They were outraged and rioted.

options.label: D
options.text: They fell asleep.

multiple-choice.question: What is the narrative of "The Rite of Spring" about?

options.label: A
options.text: A romantic love story.

options.label: B
options.text: An ancient Pagan community preparing for the sacrifice of a woman to bring about the change of seasons.

options.label: C
options.text: A group of friends on a journey.

options.label: D
options.text: A historical event.

multiple-choice.question: What was innovative about Stravinsky's composition in "The Rite of Spring"?

options.label: A
options.text: He used traditional harmonies and melodies.

options.label: B
options.text: He incorporated Russian folk music and experimented with syncopation, atonality, and multiple time signatures.

options.label: C
options.text: He wrote a simple and catchy tune.

options.label: D
options.text: He used only electronic instruments.

multiple-choice.question: Who designed the sets and costumes for the original production of "The Rite of Spring"?

options.label: A
options.text: Igor Stravinsky

options.label: B
options.text: Vaslav Nijinsky

options.label: C
options.text: Nicholas Roerich

options.label: D
options.text: Sergei Diaghilev

multiple-choice.question: How would you describe the choreography in "The Rite of Spring"?

options.label: A
options.text: Traditional and elegant.

options.label: B
options.text: Agitated and uneven, with performers cowering, writhing, and leaping about as if possessed.

options.label: C
options.text: Simple and repetitive.

options.label: D
options.text: Happy and carefree.

title: The Artists | Think Like A Coder, Ep 5

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the treehouse sanctuary established by Octavia?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide a place for people to work and earn a living.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a community where people can follow their passions and find fulfillment.

options.label: C
options.text: To serve as a military base to fight against the robots.

options.label: D
options.text: To store the Node of Power and other artifacts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the challenge that Hedge faces in defacing the paintings with an X?

options.label: A
options.text: He can only move diagonally over the canvas.

options.label: B
options.text: He can only fill in one pixel at a time and requires specific instructions.

options.label: C
options.text: He can only paint in a spiral pattern.

options.label: D
options.text: He can only use a limited amount of paint.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key insight that helps Ethic program Hedge to paint an X over each portrait?

options.label: A
options.text: To look at the grid as a series of rows and columns.

options.label: B
options.text: To look at the grid as a series of concentric squares.

options.label: C
options.text: To use a typewriter approach and paint row by row.

options.label: D
options.text: To use a random pattern to confuse the helper-bots.

multiple-choice.question: What is the advantage of the spiral approach in painting an X over each portrait?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a more generalized solution that can be adapted to fill in any pattern.

options.label: B
options.text: It is simpler and requires less logic.

options.label: C
options.text: It is faster and more efficient.

options.label: D
options.text: It is more complicated and requires more logic.

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome of Hedge defacing the portraits with an X?

options.label: A
options.text: The people in the forest are calm and unaffected.

options.label: B
options.text: The helper-bots are blamed for the vandalism and the people are distracted.

options.label: C
options.text: The garrison guarding the tower is alerted and becomes more vigilant.

options.label: D
options.text: The Node of Power is destroyed.

title: Can you solve the dragon jousting riddle? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is the frequency of the grand tournament of dragon jousting between the teams representing the elves, goblins, and treefolk?

options.label: A
options.text: Every year

options.label: B
options.text: Every five years

options.label: C
options.text: Every decade

options.label: D
options.text: Every century

multiple-choice.question: Why is the tournament conducted in absolute secret except for a group of wizards?

options.label: A
options.text: To prevent any outside meddling

options.label: B
options.text: To increase the excitement of the games

options.label: C
options.text: To give an advantage to the elves

options.label: D
options.text: To decrease the importance of the tournament

multiple-choice.question: What is the unique problem with Gorbak, the wizard who provided the scorecard information?

options.label: A
options.text: He is only able to tell the truth

options.label: B
options.text: He is only able to tell lies

options.label: C
options.text: He is only able to provide incomplete information

options.label: D
options.text: He is only able to provide irrelevant information

multiple-choice.question: What is the constraint on the total score of each match in the tournament?

options.label: A
options.text: The total score must be more than 5 hits

options.label: B
options.text: The total score must be exactly 5 hits

options.label: C
options.text: The total score must be less than or equal to 5 hits

options.label: D
options.text: There is no constraint on the total score

multiple-choice.question: What is the final score of the match between the elves and the treefolk?
